required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Retrospective Analysis of Raltegravir Use in Minority HIV Infected Women in Houston, Texas
clinical_study.official_title: A Retrospective Analysis of Raltegravir Use in Minority HIV Infected Women in Houston, Texas

lead_sponsor.agency: The University of Texas Health Science Center, Houston

clinical_study.source: The University of Texas Health Science Center, Houston

brief_summary.textblock: Raltegravir is the first marketed strand-transfer inhibitor of HIV-1 that was FDA approved in 2007. It is currently one of the preferred treatment regimens for HIV by the Department of Health and Human Services. It has become a widely used antiretroviral therapy option for HIV infected patients. It provides good tolerability and a favorable lipid profile for patients when compared to some other antiretroviral treatment options. Little data is reported about efficacy in a minority patient population. Moreover, data in an indigent minority population in the United States has not been aggregated before. Therefore this study will investigate the efficacy of raltegravir in minority women residing in Houston, TX who are HIV infected.

primary_outcome.measure: Assess the efficacy of raltegravir in study participants by measuring CD4 count and viral load

secondary_outcome.measure: Capture data on concomitant conditions that may have led to participants switching to raltegravir from medical records (eg. Diabetes mellitus)
Assess tolerability of raltegravir by capturing symptoms

arm_group.description: minority women that picked up raltegravir at Thomas street Health Center 2013

study_pop.textblock: HIV infected minority women at Thomas Street Health Center that picked up raltegravir in 2013

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. HIV-infected women who picked up raltegravir in the year 2013 at Thomas Street Health Center.
2. Minority women -Black/African American, Hispanic/Latino
Exclusion Criteria:

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: The University of Texas Health Science Center, Houston
